newsitem.title: CANADA: Westcoast hopes to hammer out rate deal.
newsitem.headline: Westcoast hopes to hammer out rate deal.

text.p: Canadian pipeline operator Westcoast Energy Inc hopes to negotiate a rate agreement with gas shippers in the next few months before its formal application is heard by regulators, president Art Willms said Wednesday.

Westcoast earlier announced it had filed a toll application with the National Energy Board that would see typical tolls rise about 25 percent next year. Willms said Westcoast hoped to reach a rate deal before NEB hearings on that application begin in February and March.
"We hope to have this (negotiations with shippers) tidied up before then," Willms said in an interview.
Saying the current system of renewing contracts every year is unworkable, the company wants to move to multi-year arrangements with tolls partly linked to moves in gas prices.
Willms said the rate application and the projected 25 percent toll increase announced Wednesday were not an attempt to pressure shippers.
"We haven't inflated the numbers. It's a reflection of the fact that (traditional rate setting methods) in today's world are not going to work," he said.
Shippers have raised concerns about Westcoast potentially having too great a market share in northeastern British Columbia for an alternative, flexible rate-setting system to be successful, he said.

If Westcoast succeeds in negotiating the type of arrangement it wants, Willms said there would be "some increased element of risk" in its earnings, especially from gathering and processing operations. He said there would be more "variability" in line with moves in gas prices.
